name: Clayton Christensen
background: Harvard Business School professor. Created theory of disruptive innovation. Wrote 'The Innovator's Dilemma'. Explained why great companies fail when facing disruptive technologies.

principles.name: The Innovator's Dilemma
principles.description: Good management practices cause great companies to fail. Listening to customers, investing in profitable products, and targeting high margins all make you vulnerable to disruption from below.
principles.falsification: When customer focus and continuous improvement successfully defend against disruption

principles.name: Disruptive innovations start worse but get better
principles.description: Disruptions initially underperform on traditional metrics but excel on new dimensions (cheaper, simpler, more convenient). Incumbents dismiss them until it's too late.
principles.falsification: When 'disruptions' fail to improve fast enough to threaten incumbents

principles.name: Jobs to be done
principles.description: Customers don't buy products - they hire them to do jobs. Understand the job, not the customer segment. Successful innovation solves jobs better than alternatives.
principles.falsification: When customer demographics and preferences genuinely predict purchasing behavior
